description: God creates the heavens and the earth.
God sends a global flood; Noah and his family survive in the ark.
Humanity builds a tower; God confuses their languages and scatters them.
God calls Abram to leave Ur and go to Canaan, promising to make him a great nation.
God destroys Sodom and Gomorrah with fire and brimstone.
Sarah bears Isaac, the son of promise, to Abraham.
God tests Abraham by asking him to sacrifice Isaac on Mount Moriah.
Isaac and Rebekah have twin sons: Esau and Jacob.
Joseph's brothers sell him to Midianite traders who take him to Egypt.
Jacob and his family (70 people) settle in Goshen, Egypt during famine.
God delivers Israel from Egypt through Moses. Pharaoh releases the Israelites after ten plagues.
note: Two main scholarly dates: early (1446 BC per 1 Kings 6:1) and late (c. 1270 BC, Ramesses II era).

event: Giving of the Law at Sinai
description: God gives the Ten Commandments and the Law to Moses on Mount Sinai.
Israel wanders in the wilderness for 40 years due to disobedience at Kadesh-barnea.
Joshua leads Israel across the Jordan and conquers Canaan, beginning with Jericho.
The walls of Jericho fall after Israel marches around the city seven times.
note: Kathleen Kenyon dated destruction to c. 1550 BC; Bryant Wood argued for c. 1400 BC.

description: Israel is led by judges (Othniel, Ehud, Deborah, Gideon, Samson, etc.) in cycles of sin, oppression, and deliverance.
The prophetess Deborah and the warrior Barak defeat the Canaanite general Sisera.
Gideon defeats a vast Midianite army with just 300 men using trumpets and torches.
Samson, a Nazirite with supernatural strength, judges Israel for 20 years.
Ruth the Moabite shows loyalty to Naomi and marries Boaz, becoming an ancestor of David and Jesus.
Samuel anoints Saul as the first king of Israel.
David becomes king of Judah (c. 1010 BC), then all Israel (c. 1003 BC).
David captures the Jebusite stronghold of Zion and makes Jerusalem his capital.
Solomon builds the First Temple in Jerusalem over seven years.
note: 1 Kings 6:1 dates it to 480 years after the Exodus.

description: After Solomon's death, the kingdom splits into Israel (north, 10 tribes) and Judah (south, 2 tribes).
The prophet Elijah confronts King Ahab and the prophets of Baal on Mount Carmel.
Assyria under Shalmaneser V / Sargon II conquers the northern kingdom of Israel. The ten tribes are deported.
note: Well-attested in Assyrian records (Sargon II's annals).

description: King Hezekiah builds a 533m tunnel to bring water from the Gihon Spring into Jerusalem before Sennacherib's siege.
note: The Siloam Inscription, found in 1880, confirms this construction.

description: Sennacherib of Assyria besieges Jerusalem but fails to take it. 185,000 Assyrian soldiers die overnight.
note: Confirmed by Sennacherib's own prism: 'I shut up Hezekiah like a caged bird.'

description: King Josiah discovers the Book of the Law in the Temple and initiates sweeping religious reforms.
Nebuchadnezzar II defeats Egypt at Carchemish, establishing Babylonian dominance over the Near East.
Nebuchadnezzar takes the first group of Jewish captives to Babylon, including Daniel.
Nebuchadnezzar destroys Jerusalem and the First Temple. The people of Judah are exiled to Babylon.
note: One of the best-attested events in biblical history; confirmed by Babylonian Chronicles.

description: Daniel is thrown into the lions' den under Darius the Mede but is miraculously preserved.
Cyrus the Great of Persia issues a decree allowing the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the Temple.
note: The Cyrus Cylinder confirms his policy of allowing exiled peoples to return home.

description: The Second Temple is completed under Zerubbabel, 70 years after the First Temple's destruction.
Queen Esther intercedes with King Ahasuerus (Xerxes I) to save the Jewish people from Haman's plot.
Ezra the priest leads a second group of exiles back to Jerusalem and restores the Law.
Nehemiah rebuilds the walls of Jerusalem in 52 days despite opposition.

event: Alexander the Great Conquers the Near East
description: Alexander's conquests spread Greek language and culture across the biblical world, fulfilling Daniel's prophecy of the he-goat.
Jewish scholars in Alexandria begin translating the Hebrew Bible into Greek (the Septuagint/LXX).
The Maccabees revolt against Seleucid king Antiochus IV Epiphanes, who desecrated the Temple. The Temple is rededicated (Hanukkah, 164 BC).
The Qumran community produces and collects biblical and sectarian manuscripts, preserved in caves near the Dead Sea.
note: Discovered 1946–1956. Contains every OT book except Esther. Confirms remarkable textual preservation.

description: Jesus is born in Bethlehem to Mary and Joseph.
note: Before the death of Herod the Great (4 BC). The census of Quirinius is debated.

description: Jesus is baptized by John the Baptist in the Jordan River. The Holy Spirit descends like a dove.
Jesus delivers the Sermon on the Mount, including the Beatitudes and the Lord's Prayer.
Jesus is crucified at Golgotha outside Jerusalem under Pontius Pilate.
note: Most scholars date it to April 7, 30 AD or April 3, 33 AD.

description: Jesus rises from the dead on the third day, appearing to many witnesses over 40 days.
The Holy Spirit descends on the apostles in Jerusalem. Peter preaches and 3,000 are saved.
Saul of Tarsus encounters the risen Christ on the road to Damascus and becomes the apostle Paul.
The apostles and elders decide that Gentile believers do not need to be circumcised.
Paul undertakes three major missionary journeys, planting churches across Asia Minor, Greece, and beyond.
Paul writes his letter to the Romans from Corinth, his most systematic theological work.
Paul arrives in Rome as a prisoner and spends two years under house arrest, continuing to preach.

event: Great Fire of Rome / Nero's Persecution
description: Rome burns; Nero blames Christians, initiating the first major Roman persecution.
Tradition holds that Peter was crucified upside down and Paul was beheaded in Rome under Nero.
Roman general Titus destroys Jerusalem and the Second Temple, fulfilling Jesus' prophecy.
note: Described in detail by Josephus (Wars of the Jews). The Arch of Titus in Rome commemorates this event.

event: Last Book of the Bible Written
description: The apostle John writes the Book of Revelation while exiled on Patmos.
note: Most scholars date Revelation to the reign of Domitian (81–96 AD).
